716734f.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716734f.text:
The Bowery, west side, between Bayard and Canal Streets, showin the Atlantic Gardens. Adjoining on the left is the Bowery Theatre which became the Thalia in 1879. Note the telegraph poles and the absence of the 3rd Avenue "El" structure. The latter, erected in 1878 evidently dates this photo.
prior to 1878
Gift of Urbrock Collection

716733f-a.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716733f-a.text:
The Bowery, west side, between Bayard and Canal Streets, showing the old Thalia Theatre and its adjoining Atlantic Gardens. On the right margin is the original Citizens Savings Bank.
1910
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Neg # 342
Neg. # 1285 (small neg.)

716606f-a.title: Manhattan: Bayard Street - Bowery
716606f-a.text:
(1)
Bayard Street, south side, at the Bowery, showing an old hip-roofed house (No. 29 Bowery), at the S.E. corner. Shown on the Bowery is the
Third Ave. Elevated Line.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Arumbruster Collection.
(2)
A side view of No. 29 Bowery, which is at the S.E. corner.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

716607f-c.title: Manhattan: Bayard Street - Bowery
716607f-c.text:
(1)
Bayard Street, west from but not including the Bowery. This view is taken during the dedication of the Gee How Oak Tong Building.
(A family brotherhood,) at No. 62 Bayard Street.
September 3, 1927,
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same showing, Bayard Street, north side, west from but not
including Elizabeth Street.
September 3, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as No. 1, but more inclusive and showing the Bowery.
September 25, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

716610f-a.title: Manhattan: Bayard Street - Bowery
716610f-a.text:
45 Bayard Street, adjoining the S.W. corner of the Bowery. Building
shown is a frame house, with a stucco front.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 14.

716735f-b.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716735f-b.text:
(1)
Bowery, west side, north from and including Bayard, to, but not including Canal Streets. The upper stories only are shown as the Third Ave., Elevated and the Manhattan Bridge Plaza obstructs the
full view.
December 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing a closer view of the lower part of the Thalia
Theatre.
December 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, as No. 2, but at a later date.
July 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

716739f-a.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716739f-a.text:
(1)
Bowery, west side, north from but not including Bayard, to and including Canal Streets.  The Thalia Theatre is shown on the extreme left, with the Atlantic Garden adjoining.
June 25, 1928
F.L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, slightly southward.  Note absence of Thalia Theatre.
September 25, 1936.
F.L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2, but at an earlier date. The Thalia Theatre, as shown here, was erected in 1826 as the Bowery Theatre; the Mayor laying the corner stone in May and it being opened in October of that year. It was destroyed by fire four times. First on May 26, 1828, when it was rebuilt and reopened in 90 days. It was destroyed again September 22, 1836; for the third time, February 8, 1838; and last on April 25, 1845. It retained the name Bowery until 1879, when it was re-christened the Thalia. Its final and last fire occured on June 15, 1929 and the remains disfigured the area for several years. Today (1937) this old landmark is completely gone, a low business structure occupying the site. The Bull's Head, a tavern used for the sale of cattle stood on this site from prior to 1763
to 1826, when it was taken down.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
